text.0: agni advances with his lofty banner the bull is bellowing to the earth and heavens.
text.1: he hath attained the skys supremest limits the steer hath waxen in the lap of waters.
text.2: the bull the youngling with the hump hath frolicked the strong and neverceasing calf hath bellowed.
text.3: bringing our offerings to the gods assembly he moves as chief in his own dwellingplaces.
text.4: him who hath grasped his parents head they stablished at sacrifice a wave of heavenly lustre.
text.5: in his swift flight the red dawns borne by horses refresh their bodies in the home of order.
text.6: for vasu thou precedest every morning and still hast been the twins illuminator.
text.7: for sacrifice seven places thou retainest while for thine own self thou engenderest mitra.
text.8: thou art the eye and guard of mighty order and varuṇa when to sacrifice thou comest.
text.9: thou art the waters child o jātavedas envoy of him whose offering thou acceptest.
text.10: thou art the leader of the rite and region to which with thine auspicious teams thou teadest.
text.11: thy lightbestowing head to heaven thou liftest making thy tongue the oblationbearer agni.
text.12: through his wise insight trita in the cavern seeking as ever the chief sires intention.
text.13: carefully tended in his parents bosom calling the weapons kin goes forth to combat.
text.14: wellskilled to use the weapons of his father Āptya urged on by indra fought the battle.
text.15: then trita slew the foe sevenrayed threeheaded and freed the cattle of the son of tvaṣṭar.
text.16: lord of the brave indra cleft him in pieces who sought to gain much strength and deemed him mighty.
text.17: he smote his three heads from his body seizing the cattle of the oniniform son of tvaṣṭar.
